OCT GCIPL demonstrates nasal thinning in both eyes. OCT RNFL demonstrates areas of thinning superiorly and nasally OD and superiorly and temporally OS.

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text: What visual field defect do you expect to see in this patient?

answers.explanation:
This patient has binasal thinning in both eyes and this would correspond to a bitemporal visual field defect since the nasal part of the macula sees the temporal visual field and vice versa. However, in this case, the patient does not have a detectable visual field defect as seen on the Humphrey 24-2 SITA-Fast visual fields below.

![](/content/media/neuro-ophthalmology-7-3.webp)

answers.answerText: D. Arcuate defects in both eyes

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

answers.explanation:
This case demonstrates a relatively new understanding in neuro-ophthalmology, where the OCT ganglion cell analysis can demonstrate abnormalities before visual field deficits, especially in optic chiasmal lesions. Vision can be preserved; however, early stage ganglion cell and retinal nerve fiber atrophy can be present. The nasal thinning OU correlates to the temporal field deficit that would be present if the disease progresses further, leading to a bitemporal hemianopia which is characteristic of optic chiasm lesions. Since this patient has findings suggestive of a lesion of the optic chiasm (even though there are no visual field defects), an MRI sella should be performed. The coronal T1-weighted MRI of the sella is shown and reveals a Rathke’s cleft cyst is shown in the red arrow, and optic chiasm is shown in the yellow arrow.

![](/content/media/neuro-ophthalmology-7-4.webp)

References

1. Tieger MG, Hedges TR, Ho J, et al. Ganglion cell complex loss in chiasmal compression by brain tumours. J Neuroophthalmol 2017;37(1):7-12.

2. Blanch RJ, Micieli JA, Oyesiku NM, Newman NJ, Biousse V. Optical coherence tomography retinal ganglion cell complex analysis for the detection of early chiasmal compression. Pituitary 2018;21(5):515-523.

answers.answerText: B. Observation for visual field defect
